Decoding Chaos in Colours

Our Project Proposal

Published

February 4, 2024

Modified

February 9, 2024

Authors: Imran, Suan Ern, Zachary Wong

Motivation

Terrorism, especially coordinated attacks targeting innocent civilians, have been a constant in our lives, threatening the public both physically and psychologically. A good visual analysis of terrorist attacks is essential to help (1) discover global terrorism trends, (2) unveil hidden relationships among terrorist networks through their attacks and (3) ascertain the impact of fatalities and losses.

The team aims to use open-source data which includes information on terrorist events globally to provide easy-to-use and insightful visualisation tools that can be especially suitable for Defence and Security sectors to develop effective counter terrorism measures and strategies.

Objectives

The objective of this project is to:

  1. Examine open-source data on terrorist events worldwide (The Global Terrorism Database(GTD)) and derive useful insights on the factors and conditions that may affect international terrorist incidents, and
  2. Build a web-enabled interactive visual analytics application by using R Shiny based on this Global Terrorism Database (GTD).

Data

The project will examine the Global Terrorism Database™ (GTD) from University of Maryland that holds 50 decades (i.e. Year 1970 to Year 2020) of attack events that happened in 203 countries. The original dataset consists of 209,706 observations and 135 variables. Given the large dataset, the team will filter the dataset to eliminate unnecessary data to ensure quality of data used is pertinent to project objective.

Methodology & Analytical Approach

For this project, the following approach will be taken by the team:

  1. Data Preparation: Clean the dataset by removing irrelevant variables, filtering variables and encoding categorical variables if necessary.

    • The table below shows the variables that we have selected to maintain.

    • For detailed description of the variables, please refer to the Code Book in the reference section.

Column Variable Column Number Column Description
eventid 1 ID labelled by GTD on each incident
iyear 2 Year of Incident
imonth 3 Month of Incident
iday 4 Day of Incident
extended 6 Did the event last more than 24 hours
country_txt 9 Country where incident occurred
region_txt 11 Region where incident occurred
provstate 12 Province or State which incident occurred
city 13 City, village or town where incident occurred
latitude 14 self-explanatory
longitude 15 self-explanatory
vicinity 17 Did even occur in immediate vicinity of the city
summary 19 Incident summary
crit1 20 Political, economic, religious or social goal
crit2 21 Intention to coerce, intimidate or publicize to larger audience(s)
crit3 22 Outside international humanitarian law
doubtterr 23 Any doubt if incident is terrorism related
alternative_txt 25 Variable identifies the most likely categorization of incident other than terrorism
multiple 26 Is attack part of a multiple incident
success 27 Whether attack was successful
suicide 28 Was it a suicide attack
attacktype1_txt 30 General method of attack based on broad class of tactics used
targtype1_txt 36 General type of target/victim
targsubtype1_txt 38 Specific target category and level of designation of target type
corp1 39 Name of corporate entity or government agency targeted
target1 40 Specific person, building or installation etc
natlty1_txt 42 Nationality of target attacked
gname 59 Perpetrator group name
motive 65 When report explicitly mentions a specific motive
individual 69 Whether attack was done by one or more individuals affiliated with a group or organization
nperps 70 Number of perpetrators
nperpcap 71 Number of perpetrators captured
claimed 72 Whether a group or person claimed the attack
claimmode_txt 74 How the person or group claimed the attack
compclaim 81 Any competing claims for the attack
weaptype1_txt 83 Main weapon type used in incident
weapsubtype1_txt 85 Sub weapon type used in incident
weapdetail 98 Any pertinent information on type of weapon used in the incident
nkill 99 Total number of fatalities
nkillter 102 Number of perpetrator fatalities
nwound 103 Number of wounded
nwoundte 104 Number of perpetrators wounded
property 105 Any property damaged as a result of incident
propextent_txt 107 Extent of property damaged
propvalue 108 Value of property damaged (in USD)
ishostkid 110 Whether victims were taken hostage or kidnapped
nhostkid 111 Number of victims taken hostage or kidnapped
nhours 113 Number of hours taken hostage or kidnapped
ndays 114 Number of days taken hostage or kidnapped
ransom 117 Any ransom demanded
ransomamt 118 Ransom amount demanded (in USD)
ransompaid 120 Was ransom paid
hostkidoutcome_txt 124 Eventual fate of hostages or kidnapped victims
addnotes 126 Any additional relevant details on the attack
INT_LOG 131 Whether attack was logistically international
INT_IDEO 132 Whether attack was ideologically international
INT_MISC 133 When the attack was international but cannot be classified under logistical or ideological
INT_ANY 134 whether attack was any of the above (internationally classified)
related 135 If the attack is part of a coordinated or multi-part incident, all incidents will be listed here and separated by commas.

  1. Exploratory Data Analysis via Data Visualisation Methods: Analyse the dataset to understand the distribution of variables, identify patterns, and explore correlation between variables. Such as using:

    1. Time-series bar/ line chart and bubble plot

    2. Geospatial heatmaps and hotspot maps

  2. Confirmatory Data Analysis via Statistical Methods: Analyse the dataset using statistical testing tools to test hypotheses, evaluate the findings and arguments (e.g. strength of relationships between variables) and make statistical observations under uncertainty.

    1. Correlation test:

      • Correlation web plot, or

      • Significant Test of Correlation: ggscatterstats()

    2. Model Diagnostic: checking for multicollinearity

    3. Model Diagnostic: checking normality assumption

    4. Oneway ANOVA Test: ggbetweenstats() method

Prototype Sketches

The following sketches were drawn to conceptualise our thoughts and discussions on the layout of the Shiny app along with its various functions. 

These will subsequently be refined as we further codify and render our graphs and application. 

The various sections of our app consists of:- 

  1. Landing page - to visually summarise the impact of Global Terrorism incidents till date 

  2. Global trends- to examine the trends over time and deep dive into the nature of events 

  3. Country statistics - to enable users to deep dive into individual countries or regions to understand the impact of Terrorism in that locality 

  4. Distribution analysis - to examine the Distribution of Terror events against categorical variable like nature of targets, weapons used and types of attacks 

  5. Confirmatory Analysis - to visualise and examine/ test for relationships, associations and correlations etc 

  • Landing Page
  • Global Trends
  • Country Statistics
  • Distribution
  • Confirmatory

This tab will serve as a “landing page” to inform and summarise the global impact till date. 

Proposed key features on the page include: 

  • World map to identify the countries/regions most impacted and location of events, based on different colour intensity, with the use of Latitude/ Longitude variables. 

  • Interactivity elements will be implemented with the tooltip information such as Country, Total Counts on Attack/ Killed/ Wounded etc. 

This tab will serve as the dashboard in the R Shiny application that will identify the most affected countries, groups with most attacks, types of weapons used, forms of attacks etc. 

Proposed key features on the page include: 

  • Interactive or Animated Bubble plot that shows the most affected countries over time, with the use of time slider or play button for animated graph. 

  • Line chart to plot how the number of attacks, casualties, wounded have changed over time, with the use of time slider or play button for animated graph. 

  • Bar chart to show the top terror groups. 

  • Word cloud to visualise the motives behind the attacks. 

  • World map to show the changes in terrorism “hotspots” over time. 

  • Interactivity elements will be implemented with the tooltip information such as Country, Counts on Total Attack/ Total Killed/ Total Wounded etc. 

This tab will serve as a continuation from the ‘Global Trends’ tab.  

Proposed key features on the page include: 

  • World map, line/ bar chart and word cloud will show the details at regional level. 

  • Users will be able to select from the dropdown list for the country/ region that they would want to examine in more detail. 

This tab will display the distribution of Terror events based on the different categorical variables such as Target/ Weapon/ Attack/ Region etc. 

Proposed key features on the page include: 

  • Bar charts and ridge density plots to show the distribution of the terror events based on the different variables. 

This tab will examine and visualise the relationships, associations and correlations of different variables. 

Proposed key features on the page include: 

  • Association tests between categorical variables eg: ‘Modus operandi’ Vs Targets types. 

  • Time series seasonality test to examine if there is any seasonal element in attacks. 

  • Statistical test plots such as tests of correlation, multicollinearity, normality testing, etc. 

R Packages

Our team intends to use the following R packages to run the R Shiny Application:

  • tidyverse: a family of modern R packages specially designed to support data science, analysis and communication task including creating static statistical graphs.

  • knitr: an report generation tool.

  • dplyr: an R tool for working with data frame (e.g. objects).

  • ggstatsplot: an extension of ggplot2 package for statistical visualisation and graphics creation.

  • ggdist: an R package that support visualisation of distribution and uncertainty.

  • ggiraph: for making ‘ggplot’ graphics interactive.

  • plotly: R library for plotting interactive statistical graphs.

  • performance: an R package used for assessment, comparison and testing of statistical models.

  • parameters: an R package used for processing parameters of various statistical models.

  • RColorBrewer: an R package that provide various colour schemes and colour palettes.

  • DT: an R interface to the JavaScript library DataTables that create interactive table on html page.

Project Schedule

Below is an overview of our project timeline. For detailed list of task, please refer to gantt chart submitted.

plot(gc, event.label = "Due\n31 Mar", event.time = "2024-03-31",
     col.event=c("salmon"),
     col.done=c("#459397"),
     col.notdone=c("salmon"),
     main="Project Timeline"
     )
legend("topright", pch=21, pt.cex=1, cex=0.7, pt.bg=c("#459397", "salmon"),
     border="black",
     legend=c("Completed", "In progress"), bg="white", xpd=TRUE)
